title: 108_s1967
content: The Act titled "Interest on Business Checking Act of 2003" authorizes interest-bearing transaction accounts for all businesses. The Act "Interest on Business Checking Act of 2003" allows depository institutions to permit owners of certain accounts to make up to 24 transfers per month to another account in the same institution. The Act allows depository institutions to permit account owners to make transfers to another account in the same institution, subject to certain limitations. The Act allows depository institutions to permit account owners to make transfers to another account in the same institution, subject to limitations. Amendments made by the Act clarify that no institution prohibited by law can offer demand deposit accounts. The effective date for these amendments is 2 years after the Act's enactment. Authorization of interest-bearing transaction accounts. Repeal of prohibition on payment of interest on demand deposits under various acts and joint rulemaking required within 2 years. The Federal Deposit Insurance Act is repealed, and joint rulemaking is required within 2 years to authorize the payment of interest and dividends on transaction accounts at depository institutions regulated by the Secretary of the Treasury and Federal banking agencies. Regulations must establish the scope of authorization, types of accounts, and any limitations or restrictions consistent with the section's purposes. The regulations required by this subsection, which must take effect within 2 years of the Act's enactment, define terms such as "depository institution" and "transaction account" as per the Federal Reserve Act. The regulations also include limitations, exceptions, or restrictions on authorization, in line with the section's objectives. The terms "depository institution" and "transaction account" are defined in accordance with the Federal Reserve Act. The term "Federal banking agency" is defined as per the Federal Deposit Insurance Act. The amendments will become effective either 2 years after the enactment of the Act or when final regulations are issued under subsection (b). SEC. 4. PAYMENT OF INTEREST ON RESERVES AT FEDERAL RESERVE BANKS. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to allow depository institutions to earn interest on balances maintained at a Federal Reserve bank, with regulations set by the Board for payment and distribution of earnings. The Board may issue regulations on the payment and distribution of earnings to depository institutions maintaining balances at Federal Reserve banks. The National Credit Union Administration Central Liquidity Facility governs the crediting and distribution of earnings for balances held in Federal Reserve banks by depository institutions, including trust companies, certain corporations, and branches of foreign banks. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to include trust companies, certain corporations, and branches of foreign banks. Amendments are made to Section 19 regarding member banks and technical changes are implemented. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to include trust companies, certain corporations, and branches of foreign banks. Section 19 is amended to remove certain provisions and make technical changes. SEC. 5 amends the Federal Reserve Act to increase flexibility in setting reserve requirements. The ratio can now be not greater than 3 percent (including zero) and not less than 8 percent (including zero). SEC. 6 addresses the treatment of certain escrow accounts. SEC. 6 addresses the treatment of escrow accounts for real estate transactions, excluding certain activities from being considered as interest payments under various laws. The Federal Deposit Insurance Act excludes certain activities related to escrow accounts from being considered as interest payments under various laws. These activities include absorbing expenses, forbearing from charging fees, and providing benefits to account holders.
